awd_titl_txt: III: Medium: Collaborative Research: Spatial Data and Trajectory Data Management on GPUs
awd_abstract_narration:
Although locating and navigation devices embedded in smartphones have already generated large volumes of location and trajectory data, the next generation of consumer electronics are likely to generate even larger volumes of location-dependent data where spatial and trajectory data management techniques will play critical roles in understanding the data to facilitate decision making. Modern Graphics Processing Units (GPUs) are capable of general computing. Current generation of commodity GPUs have large numbers of processing cores, support even larger numbers of current threads and provide high memory bandwidth, yet are available at affordable prices. The massively data parallel computing power of GPUs makes the hardware ideal for spatial and trajectory data management which is both data and computing intensive.

This project develops parallel indexing structures and query processing algorithms for spatial and trajectory data on GPUs to provide high performance which is crucial in speeding up existing applications and enabling new scientific and business inquiries.  The project achieves its goals by developing: 1) novel spatial indexing techniques on GPUs; 2) novel spatial joins on GPUs; 3) novel trajectory segmentation and indexing techniques and trajectory similarity query processing techniques on GPUs; and 4) an end-to-end prototype system incorporated with open source database and GIS systems for performance evaluations and real world applications. Compared with existing spatial and trajectory data management systems that are mostly disk-resident and adopt a serial CPU computing model, the performance of GPU accelerated main-memory based systems is expected to achieve several orders of magnitude speedup and brings the performance of spatial and trajectory queries to a new level.  The research results are beneficial to many applications, such as transportation, urban planning, wild bird ecology, and epidemiology of infectious diseases.  Collaboration is carried out with transportation engineers at the University Transportation Research Center in New York City and ecology scientists at the University of Oklahoma?s Earth Observing and Modelling Facility.  The project also makes important impacts on education as it provides training for students in the areas of national critical needs: database research, high performance computing, GPU programming, GIS, transportation, mobile and ecology applications. The developed algorithms and prototype system, real datasets and performance evaluation results are made available to the public at the Website: http://www.cs.ou.edu/~database.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Although locating and navigation devices embedded in smartphones have already generated large volumes of location and trajectory data, the next generation of consumer electronics are likely to generate even larger volumes of location-dependent data where spatial and trajectory data management techniques will play critical roles in understanding the data to facilitate decision making. Modern Graphics Processing Units (GPUs) are capable of general computing. Current generation of commodity GPUs have large numbers of processing cores, support even larger numbers of current threads and provide high memory bandwidth, yet are available at affordable prices. The massively data parallel computing power of GPUs makes the hardware ideal for spatial and trajectory data management which is both data and computing intensive.

This project developed parallel indexing structures and query processing algorithms for spatial and trajectory data on GPUs to provide high performance which is crucial in speeding up existing Big Data applications and enabling new scientific and business inquiries. The project achieved its goals by developing: 1) novel spatial indexing techniques on GPUs; 2) novel spatial joins on GPUs; 3) novel trajectory segmentation and indexing techniques and trajectory similarity query processing techniques on GPUs; 4) novel Top-K query processing algorithms on GPUs; and 5) novel algorithms for trajectory clustering on GPUs to estimate trajectories in uncertain trajectory data. 

Compared with existing spatial and trajectory data management systems that are mostly disk-resident and adopt a serial CPU computing model, the performance of the GPU accelerated main-memory based systems developed in this project achieved several orders of magnitude speedup and brought the performance of spatial and trajectory queries to a new level. For example, spatially joining ~170 million NYC taxi pickup locations and taxi zones, census tracts and census blocks with hundreds to tens of thousands of polygons take sub-second runtime on an Nvidia V100 GPU. In comparison, it would take tens of hours using PostgreSQL with PostGIS plugin on a modern CPU system. Similarly, computing pairwise Hausdorff distances among 10,700 trajectories takes about 13.5 seconds on a V100 GPU while it would take more than 5 hours using SciPy API on an Intel i7-6700K CPU.  The project?s research results were reported in 41 peer-reviewed international publications.

For broader impacts in terms of applications, the project conducted comprehensive experiments evaluating the developed algorithms using real data from transportation and biodiversity applications. The project also had important impacts on education and diversity as it provided training for 10 PhD students (4 of whom were female) , 7 MS students (2 of whom were female), and 1 female undergraduate student in the research areas of national critical needs: database management, data mining, high performance computing, GPU programming, and GIS. 

For industry collaboration, the project also collaborated with the Open GPU Data Science project RAPIDS (https://rapids.ai/) at Nvidia and helped create and develop the open source cuSpatial project (https://github.com/rapidsai/cuspatial) as an integrated component of RAPIDS on spatial and trajectory data management.  cuSpatial implements several algorithms that were developed in this project with multi-programming language APIs including C++, Python and Java with accessible, verifiable and demonstrated efficiency. With the increasing adoptions of both cuSpatail and other RAPIDS components in both source code and binary Anaconda package distributions, the research results have the potential to reach a larger user community through academia-industry collaboration beyond this project's lifetime.


Last Modified: 11/24/2022
Modified by: Le Gruenwald

    Jianting Zhang and Le Gruenwald

    Le Gruenwald
